desc: MAP3K13 encodes a serine/threonine kinase and component of the pro-oncogenic MAP-kinase and JNK signaling pathways.

The MAP3K13 gene encodes a serine/threonine kinase that is a member of the mixed lineage kinase (MLK) family in the JNK pathway. The JNK pathway, a MAP-kinase pathway, is activated in response to proinflammatory cytokines and extracellular stresses (PMID: 11163770). It plays a role in cellular proliferation, apoptosis and morphogenesis (PMID: 9561845). Significant roles in this signaling cascade are played by MAPK (JNK), MAPKKs (MKK7 and SEK1/MKK4) and a variety of MAPKKKs, including MEKK1, ASK1, TAK1 and MLK family proteins (e.g. MAP3K13) (PMID: 11163770, 8637721). The MAP3K13 protein consists of a catalytic domain followed by a double leucine/isoleucine zipper. Through the leucine/isoleucine zipper domain, MAP3K13 forms dimers or oligomers with other proteins, such as JNK interacting protein (JIP-1), an interaction that is essential for the activation of MKK7 in the JNK signaling cascade (PMID: 9353328, 11163770, 11726227). MAP3K13 mRNA is found primarily in the pancreas, with lower levels of expression in the brain, liver and placenta (PMID: 9353328). Amplification and missense mutations of MAP3K13 are found in various solid tumors, including breast and lung cancer, and melanoma (PMID: 22722201, 22817889; cBioPortal, MSKCC, Oct. 2015).
